description: Largely known for the Ashwell hoard, the site is a complex not only including a temple, but also a shrine enclosing a springhead, accommodation, and workshops. There are other nearby temple sites at Barkway and Aston.
bibliography: Jackson, R, and G Burleigh. “The Senuna Treasure and Shrine at Ashwell (Herts).” In Continuity and Innovation in Religion in the Roman West, 1:37–54. Ournal of Roman Archaeology Supplementary 67, 2007.
Jackson, Ralph, and Gilbert Burleigh. Dea Senuna: Treasure, Cult and Ritual at Ashwell, Hertfordshire. British Museum, 2018.
Martyn, Blick, Brindle, and et al. “Ashwell, near Baldock (Hertfordshire).” The Rural Settlement of Roman Britain: an online resource, 2015. https://doi.org/10.5284/1030449.
Richardson, I. “PAS-9708E3: A ROMAN HOARD.” Portable Antiquities Scheme, 2012. https://finds.org.uk/database/artefacts/record/id/509533#1.
